answerText: Go Tell it on the Mountain [10] Go Tell it on the Mountain is a semi-autobiographical account of this author's childhood. He also wrote Blues for Mister Charlie and The Fire Next Time.
heading: ACF Winter |2009 | UC San Diego and Washington University and Chicago B | 1 | Literature | American | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: Brother Elisha stays up with the protagonist, who has a hallucination and believes he sees the Lord in "The Threshing-Floor," the final part of this novel.  [10] Fourteen year-old John struggles with his domineering preacher father Gabriel in this novel set in 1930's Harlem.
